Figure AI technological advancements in humanoid robotics
Key advancements by Figure AI in humanoid robotics
Investors supporting humanoid robots development by Figure AI
Evolution of competition in humanoid robot market due to Figure AI innovation
Responses of humanoid robot market to Figure AI innovations
Major achievements in Figure AI humanoid robot development
Figure AI expansion impact on AI humanoid robots
Figure AI growth plans effect on AI robots landscape

title: Figure AI in Talks for New Funding at $39 . 5 Billion Valuation – TechStory
content:
Title: Figure AI in Talks for New Funding at $39.5 Billion Valuation

Extracted Content:
Figure AI is currently in talks for new funding at a valuation of $39.5 billion. This potential funding round could significantly boost the company's growth and expansion plans. Stay tuned for more updates on this developing story.

title: Figure AI just took a step toward smarter robots - starting with ketchup in the fridge .
content:
Figure AI just took a step toward smarter robots - starting with ketchup in the fridge. 

The content associated with this title is about Figure AI's advancements in creating smarter robots by teaching them to recognize and manipulate objects in a household setting. This includes the ability to identify and handle items like ketchup bottles in a refrigerator. The article discusses how this technology could lead to more efficient and capable robots in various industries.

title: US startup reports  major breakthrough  in robot intelligence
content:
US startup reports major breakthrough in robot intelligence.

A US startup has announced a major breakthrough in robot intelligence, claiming that their new technology will revolutionize the industry. The company, which has been working on this project for several years, says that their robots will now be able to learn and adapt to new situations in real-time, making them much more versatile and capable than ever before.

This development is seen as a significant step forward in the field of robotics, with experts predicting that it will have far-reaching implications for a wide range of industries. The startup has already received significant interest from potential investors and partners, who are eager to see how this new technology will be implemented in the real world.

Overall, this breakthrough represents a major milestone in the ongoing development of artificial intelligence and robotics, and is likely to have a profound impact on the way we interact with machines in the future.

title: Figure AI is in talks to raise $1 . 5B at 15x its last valuation
content: Figure AI is in talks to raise a massive $1.5 billion round at a $39.5 billion valuation, which is 15 times higher than its last valuation of $2.6 billion. The current round is expected to be led by Align Ventures and Parkway Venture Capital. Figure AI builds humanoid robots for commercial and residential purposes and has already sold some robots to BMW. Its founder, Brett Adcock, mentioned that Figure has signed on a second commercial customer and sees the potential to ship 100,000 humanoid robots.

title: ET Graphics : Another ChatGPT moment , robot househelps
content:
ET Graphics: Another ChatGPT moment, robot househelps

In the beginning of 2025, Nvidia founder Jensen Huang had said that the “ChatGPT moment for robotics” is around the corner. Robotics company Figure AI this week made headlines when it demonstrated that robots could sort packages at a logistics unit at human speed. Founder Brett Adcock said Figure will be able to bring robots to homes within two years. Figure 02 robots can also now reason with Helix AI and do not need any fine tuning of models. Last month, Norway’s 1X also debuted its Neo Gamma humanoid robot which can carry out housework and has better conversational skills. ET’s Himanshi Lohchab looks at how robotics companies are bringing us closer to AGI with robots.

title: No , Apple and Meta arent making humanoid robots
content:
No, Apple and Meta aren't making humanoid robots

Tech press-landi and the tech blogosphere were abuzz last week with news that both Apple and Meta are making full-size, humanoid robots. However, this information is not accurate. 

Apple is exploring both humanoid and non-humanoid robots for its future smart home ecosystem, but they are leaning away from humanoid robots. Their first robot is likely to be an Apple HomePod that moves, with an estimated launch date of 2026 or 2027. 

On the other hand, Meta has formed a new team to work on developing sensors, AI, and other software for companies building humanoid robots. They believe in the vision of consumer robots that resemble people. 

Both companies are investing in robotics to improve user experience and expand their portfolios. The robotics market is projected to be worth hundreds of billions of dollars by 2035, and the companies need to compete for robotics talent to stay relevant. 

In conclusion, while Apple and Meta are investing in robotics, they are not planning to build and sell humanoid robots. The focus is on using robotics to enhance user experience and advance their technology portfolios.

title: AI robots company shifts headquarters to big San Jose office building
content:
AI robotics company shifts headquarters to San Jose office building

Figure AI, a company that makes robots enhanced by artificial intelligence, has shifted its headquarters to an office building in San Jose in a major expansion for the tech firm. The AI robotics company moved from its much smaller headquarters in Sunnyvale to an office and research building at 3960 North First St. The new headquarters site is part of the Assembly at North First tech campus in north San Jose. The North First building totals 98,700 square feet, which means it could support up to 500 workers. In February 2024, Figure AI landed $675 million through a capital raise from Microsoft, OpenAI Startup Fund, Nvidia, Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, Parkway Venture Capital, Intel Capital and others. The funding round pointed to a valuation of $2.6 billion for Figure AI. CEO Brett Adcock stated that the new location will also support manufacturing, fleet operations, and overall engineering/design build-out.

title: Meta plans  major investment  into humanoid robots , Bloomberg reports
content:
Meta plans ‘major investment’ into humanoid robots, Bloomberg reports

Meta has identified that its “next big bet” will be on AI-powered humanoid robots as the company makes “significant investment” into the category and is forming a new team within its Reality Labs hardware division to conduct the work, people with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg’s Mark Gurman. Meta plans to work on its own humanoid robot hardware, with an initial focus on household chores, though it aims to make the underlying AI, sensors and software for robots that will be manufactured and sold by a range of companies, the people say. Meta has started discussing its plan with robotics companies, including Unitree Robotics and Figure AI, but does not plan to build a Meta-branded robot initially.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Meta to invest in AI - powered humanoid robots
content: Mark Zuckerberg's Meta is establishing a new division within its Reality Labs unit to develop AI-powered humanoid robots that can assist with physical tasks. The Facebook parent company is entering the competitive field of humanoid robotics, joining rivals such as Nvidia-backed Figure AI and Tesla. Meta's Chief Technology Officer, Andrew Bosworth, mentioned in an internal memo that the robotics product group will focus on research and development involving consumer humanoid robots with a goal of maximizing Llama's platform capabilities. The group will be led by Marc Whitten, the former CEO of self-driving car company Cruise, whom Meta has hired for the role. Tesla CEO Elon Musk has also mentioned their humanoid robot "Optimus" that could perform daily tasks and eventually be sold to customers. Meta plans to develop its own humanoid robot hardware initially targeting household chores and aims to create AI, sensors, and software to power robots manufactured and sold by various companies. The company has started discussing its plan with robotics companies like Unitree Robotics and Figure AI.

title: Tesla Rival Figure AI Ends Collaboration With OpenAI After  Major Breakthrough , Says It Will Show  Something No One Has Ever Seen On A Humanoid  In Next 30 Days - Tesla ( NASDAQ : TSLA )
content:
Tesla Rival Figure AI Ends Collaboration With OpenAI After 'Major Breakthrough,' Says It Will Show 'Something No One Has Ever Seen On A Humanoid' In Next 30 Days

Robotics company Figure AI is leaving its collaboration agreement with OpenAI following a ‘major breakthrough’ on its in-house robot AI, the company’s CEO Brett Adcock said in a social media post on Tuesday.

“We’re excited to show you in the next 30 days something no one has ever seen on a humanoid,” the founder said, without providing more details.

Figure AI did not immediately respond to Benzinga’s request for a comment.

OpenAI and Figure announced a partnership in February last year to develop AI models for humanoid robots. The ChatGPT parent company is also an investor in the robotics company.

Figure AI was launched in 2022 with the aim of developing humanoids to address labor shortages and reduce the number of workers in unsafe jobs. In August, the company unveiled Figure 02, weighing 70 kg and 5’6 tall.

The company then said the robot will have a five-hour runtime and be capable of speech-to-speech conversation with humans, thanks to custom AI models trained in partnership with OpenAI.

The Figure founder’s announcement is in line with Tesla’s approach. The EV giant is also developing a humanoid robot nicknamed Optimus which is being trained with the company’s in-house AI.

Tesla CEO Elon Musk said late last month that the company intends to make several thousand units of its Optimus humanoid robot this year for deployment in its factory which will inform the next version of the robot slated for launch next year and likely to be sold to rival companies.

title: Nvidia is helping humanoid robots learn through Apple Vision Pro instruction
content: Nvidia is helping humanoid robots learn through Apple Vision Pro instruction. Robotics have been a foundational element of Nvidia’s growth, with the announcement of GR00T in March of last year. At CES, CEO Jensen Huang unveiled Blueprint, a new modality based on imitation learning. This method involves a person performing an action that the robot then imitates, allowing for effective education of humanoid robots. With GR00T Blueprint, users can create actions using Apple's Vision Pro, which are captured as a digital twin for the robot to execute in simulation.

title: Robotics startup Figure AI in talks for new funding at $39 . 5 billion valuation , Bloomberg News reports
content: Robotics startup Figure AI is in talks with investors to raise $1.5 billion in funding that would value the company at $39.5 billion, Bloomberg News reported on Friday, citing people familiar with the matter. Last year, Figure AI raised $675 million in a funding round, with investors such as Nvidia, Microsoft, and Amazon.com founder Jeff Bezos, valuing the company at $2.6 billion. Major tech companies, including Nvidia, Meta Platforms, and Tesla, alongside various startups, are diving into the competitive field of humanoid robotics, driven by advanced AI models that are accelerating innovation in robotics and automation. Meta Platforms is establishing a new division within its Reality Labs unit to develop AI-powered humanoid robots that can assist with physical tasks. In 2024, Tesla's chief executive Elon Musk said that the company's humanoid robots, called Optimus, could potentially be ready by the end of the following year. Humanoid robots have sparked renewed investor interest as AI-powered software expands the possibilities for human-robot interaction and collaboration.

title: OpenAI plans to build advanced humanoid robots after investing big in startups
content: OpenAI plans to build advanced humanoid robots after investing big in startups. A recent report by The Information suggests that OpenAI has internally discussed developing its own line of humanoid robots. According to TechCrunch, this report relies on information provided by two individuals with “direct knowledge” of the discussions. Limited information is available about OpenAI's potential humanoid robot project. Specifically, the timeline for the robot's introduction and its intended applications remain uncertain. In 2021, OpenAI closed its robotics division, which halted its ambitions in that field. However, the company recently announced the re-establishment of its robotics research group after a three-year hiatus. If OpenAI were to re-enter the robotics space, it would face stiff competition from existing players. This ambitious move would place OpenAI alongside industry giants like Nvidia and Tesla, who are already heavily invested in this burgeoning field. Reportedly, the humanoid robot market is expected to grow significantly, reaching a projected value of $66 billion by 2032. Earlier this year in February, OpenAI participated in a $625 million funding round for Figure AI Inc. Figure AI's latest creation, the Figure 02 humanoid robot, leverages AI models developed with OpenAI's assistance. These partnerships could provide a valuable foundation for OpenAI's own robotic endeavors, and expedite the development process. Before its closure, OpenAI's robotics division achieved several significant research milestones, including successfully training a robotic arm to solve a Rubik's Cube and the open-sourcing of Roboschool, a suite of simulation tools for training robot AI. As per Reuters, OpenAI is collaborating with Broadcom and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co to create an “inference processor.” This partnership could facilitate the development of a specialized chip optimized for powering the AI software within OpenAI's humanoid robots.

title: Robotics startup Figure AI in talks for new funding at $39 . 5 billion valuation , source says
content: Robotics startup Figure AI is in talks to raise $1.5 billion in funding that would value the company at $39.5 billion, with Parkway Venture Capital expected to lead the Series C round, according to a person familiar with the matter. Major tech companies, including Nvidia, Meta Platforms, and Tesla, alongside various startups, are rushing to make humanoid robots, as advanced AI models accelerate innovation in robotics and automation. Companies are betting on humanoid robots to meet potential labor shortages and perform repetitive tasks that could be dangerous or tedious such as logistics, warehousing, and manufacturing. Figure AI counts German automaker BMW as a customer. Last year, the startup said it raised $675 million in a funding round, with big-name investors such as OpenAI, Nvidia, Microsoft, and Amazon.com founder Jeff Bezos, valuing the company at $2.6 billion. Figure AI's founder and CEO Brett Adcock said last week that the startup exited its collaboration agreement with ChatGPT-maker OpenAI, citing an internal breakthrough in AI for robots. "Figure's AI models are built entirely in-house, making external AI partnerships not just cumbersome but ultimately irrelevant to our success," Adcock posted on X. Bloomberg News initially reported the development and said that Align Ventures is expected to co-lead the funding round for Figure AI, along with Parkway Venture Capital. Align Ventures and Figure AI did not immediately respond to requests for comment on the report. Separately, Meta Platforms is establishing a new division within its Reality Labs unit to develop AI-powered humanoid robots that can assist with physical tasks, according to an internal company memo viewed by Reuters on Friday. In 2024, Tesla's chief executive, Elon Musk, said that the company's humanoid robots, called Optimus, could potentially be ready by the end of the following year.

title: Arcapita & Parkway invest in a portfolio of high growth Artificial Intelligence companies
content:
Arcapita Group Holdings Limited (“Arcapita”), the global alternative investment firm, announced its co-investment in a high-growth portfolio of Artificial Intelligence (“AI”) companies in partnership with Parkway Venture Capital (“Parkway”), a U.S.-based venture capital firm specializing in frontier technology. This investment has been structured to offer investors with a unique opportunity to gain exposure to early-stage, pioneering companies at the forefront of the AI revolution.

The Artificial Intelligence Portfolio will initially deploy its capital in five seed assets driving advancements in robotics, quantum computing, generative AI and more. Notable investments include:
- Figure AI: A leader in AI-powered humanoid robotics, focused on addressing labor shortages and improving workplace safety through cutting-edge automation. Figure AI has secured strategic partnerships with BMW and Amazon, as well as investments from Microsoft, OpenAI, and Nvidia.
- SandboxAQ: Originally developed within Alphabet Inc., SandboxAQ applies AI and quantum computing to advance cybersecurity and materials science, with backing from former Google CEO, Eric Schmidt, Salesforce’s Marc Benioff, and Allianz.

Neil Carter, Managing Director of US Private Equity at Arcapita, said, “Arcapita’s vision is to support businesses that are defining the future. In Parkway we have found an ideal partner for our first U.S.-based VC investment. They have a strong track record of identifying and nurturing high-potential companies at the cutting-edge and we are very excited by the seed investments in our Artificial Intelligence Portfolio. Together, we aim to unlock opportunities that have a profound and lasting impact on industries worldwide.”

Jesse Coors-Blankenship, General Partner, Parkway, said: “This collaboration is a defining moment for Parkway as it will empower us to scale our global reach and deepen our impact in pioneering technologies, delivering results that shape industries and redefine possibilities.” Continuing, Gregg Hill, General Partner at Parkway, said: “Arcapita’s trust in Parkway underscores not only the strength of our approach, but also our collective commitment to driving meaningful global innovation.”

title: Arcapita & Parkway invest in a portfolio of high - growth Artificial Intelligence companies
content:
Arcapita Group Holdings Limited (Arcapita), the global alternative investment firm, announced its co-investment in a high-growth portfolio of Artificial Intelligence (AI) companies in partnership with Parkway Venture Capital (Parkway), a U.S.-based venture capital firm specializing in frontier technology. This investment has been structured to offer investors with a unique opportunity to gain exposure to early-stage, pioneering companies at the forefront of the AI revolution.

This investment highlights Arcapita’s commitment to advancing emerging technologies and AI, underscoring its vision for fostering innovation and growth in these transformative sectors. The partnership also reinforces Parkway’s reputation as a leader in frontier technology and artificial intelligence, paving the way for continued expansion and success.

The Artificial Intelligence Portfolio will initially deploy its capital in five seed assets driving advancements in robotics, quantum computing, generative AI and more.

Notable investments include:
- Figure AI: A leader in AI-powered humanoid robotics, focused on addressing labor shortages and improving workplace safety through cutting-edge automation. Figure AI has secured strategic partnerships with BMW and Amazon, as well as investments from Microsoft, OpenAI, and Nvidia.
- SandboxAQ: Originally developed within Alphabet Inc., SandboxAQ applies AI and quantum computing to advance cybersecurity and materials science, with backing from former Google CEO, Eric Schmidt, Salesforce’s Marc Benioff, and Allianz.

The global AI market is expected to see a compound annual growth rate of 28% between 2024 and 2030 because of an increase in AI adoption across multiple industries, technological advancements, data availability and government support.

Neil Carter, Managing Director of US Private Equity at Arcapita, said, “Arcapita’s vision is to support businesses that are defining the future. In Parkway we have found an ideal partner for our first U.S.-based VC investment. They have a strong track record of identifying and nurturing high-potential companies at the cutting-edge and we are very excited by the seed investments in our Artificial Intelligence Portfolio. Together, we aim to unlock opportunities that have a profound and lasting impact on industries worldwide.”

Jesse Coors-Blankenship, General Partner, Parkway, said: “This collaboration is a defining moment for Parkway as it will empower us to scale our global reach and deepen our impact in pioneering technologies, delivering results that shape industries and redefine possibilities.” Gregg Hill, General Partner at Parkway, added: “Arcapita’s trust in Parkway underscores not only the strength of our approach, but also our collective commitment to driving meaningful global innovation.”

title: New Meta Reality Labs Division To Develop AI - Driven Humanoid Robots
content:
New Meta Reality Labs Division To Develop AI-Driven Humanoid Robots
After splitting Reality Labs into “Wearables” and “Metaverse” divisions this past summer, Meta is further restructuring its virtual reality/augmented reality (VR/AR) hardware department by establishing a new unit focused on developing artificial intelligence (AI)-powered humanoid robots designed to assist with physical household tasks, according to an internal company memo.
In the memo, Meta CTO Andrew Bosworth says that the robotics product group will focus on research and development around “consumer humanoid robots” with a goal of “maximizing” the platform capabilities of Llama, the company's family of automated open-source large language models.
The new division will be led by Marc Whitten, the former CEO of Cruise, a self-driving car company that General Motors spent billions on before it was shuttered this past week.
Investing in the development of AI-powered human-like robots will put Meta in direct competition with other tech companies like Apptronik and Nvidia-backed Figure AI, as well as Tesla, which built a humanoid robot called “Optimus” that, according to CEO Elon Musk, can perform daily tasks.
Meta’s robotics division will target household chores as well as the creation of AI, sensors and software that are able to power robots and can be sold on the open market to companies like Unitree Robotics and Figure AI, which Meta has already been in discussions with.
In its last quarterly report, the Facebook parent company showed signs of hope for its Reality Labs department, which has suffered an operating loss of over $60 billion since 2020.
Although the VR/AR division continues to lose billions, the department exceeded Q4 expectations, generating $1.1 billion in sales -- a 40% year-over-year bump.
By dividing Reality Labs in June, Meta aimed to showcase the success and popularity of its Ray-Ban Smart Glasses, which have taken on new features like live AI chatbot accessibility, with plans for a 3D display.

title: Google introduces new AI models for rapidly growing robotics industry
content:
Google introduces new AI models for rapidly growing robotics industry

Alphabet’s Google launched two new AI models tailored for robotics applications on Wednesday based on its Gemini 2.0 model, as it looks to cater to the rapidly growing robotics industry. The robotics field has made large strides over the past few years with increasing advancements in AI and improving models, speeding up commercialization of robots largely in industrial settings, according to industry experts.

Google’s launch comes a month after robotics startup Figure AI exited its collaboration agreement with ChatGPT-maker OpenAI after it made an internal breakthrough in AI for robots. The search engine giant’s Gemini Robotics is an advanced vision-language-action model that will have physical actions as a way to provide output. The second model, named Gemini Robotics-ER, will enable a robot to have an advanced understanding of the space around it and lets developers run their own programs using reasoning abilities offered by Gemini 2.0.

Google said its models are designed for robots of all form factors including humanoids and other types used in factories and warehouses. Using robotics-focused AI models developed by the likes of Google and OpenAI can help cash-strapped startups reduce development costs and increase the speed at which they can take their product to market. Google said it tested the Gemini Robotics model on data from its bi-arm robotics platform, ALOHA 2, but can be specialized for complex use cases such as Apptronik’s Apollo robot. Apptronik raised $350 million in a funding round last month led by B Capital and Capital Factory, with participation from Google to scale production of AI-powered humanoid robots. Google had bought robotics pioneer Boston Dynamics in 2013, and sold the company, known for its dog-like and humanoid robots, to SoftBank Group Corp about four years later.

title: OpenAI startup empire : The companies backed by its venture fund
content:
OpenAI’s startup empire: The companies backed by its venture fund
Since its founding in 2021, OpenAI Startup Fund has raised $175 million for its main fund and secured an additional $114 million through five separate special purpose vehicles, which are investment pools for specific opportunities. Unlike many sizable tech companies, OpenAI says it doesn’t use the company’s money to invest in startups. The ChatGPT maker says its OpenAI Startup Fund is raised from outside investors. This includes participation from significant OpenAI backer Microsoft, as well as “other OpenAI partners,” according to the fund’s website. The OpenAI Startup Fund, which is managed by a dedicated team, has so far invested in over a dozen startups, according to data providers PitchBook and Crunchbase and TechCrunch’s research. The following companies, organized alphabetically, have themselves announced investments from the fund.

title: Arcapita , Parkway invest in portfolio of high growth Artificial Intelligence companies

This investment has been structured to offer investors with a unique opportunity to gain exposure to early-stage, pioneering companies at the forefront of the AI revolution.

The partnership also reinforces Parkway’s reputation as a leader in frontier technology and artificial intelligence, paving the way for continued expansion and success.

The Artificial Intelligence Portfolio will initially deploy its capital in five seed assets driving advancements in robotics, quantum computing, generative AI and more. Notable investments include:

- Figure AI: A leader in AI-powered humanoid robotics, focused on addressing labor shortages and improving workplace safety through cutting-edge automation. Figure AI has secured strategic partnerships with BMW and Amazon, as well as investments from Microsoft, OpenAI, and Nvidia.

The global AI market is expected to see a compound annual growth rate of 28% between 2024 and 2030 because of an increase in AI adoption across multiple industries, technological advancements, data availability and government support.

They have a strong track record of identifying and nurturing high-potential companies at the cutting-edge and we are very excited by the seed investments in our Artificial Intelligence Portfolio. title: High tech robot dog can swim , climb walls and even snowboard – but it will cost you £14k
content:
High tech robot dog can swim, climb walls and even snowboard – but it will cost you £14k

A robot dog costing £14k has a whole heap of mad tricks up its sleeve - 'the 'Lynx' robot can climb walls and tackle tricky terrain but has a limited battery life

A state-of-the-art robot dog has been captured showing off its crazy dance moves in all kinds of tough terrain. The Lynx robot dog has been designed to access some of the Earth’s most inhospitable locations. It was created by the Chinese company Deep Robotics to conduct search and rescue operations and help aid scientific exploration. And while it can roll over like any self-respecting pooch, it also has the ability to climb walls, snowboard and even swim.

The robot is helped by the possession of wheels instead of paws and its talents were recently showcased in a rather astonishing video. The Lynx can climb 8.7-inch steps and tackle 45-degree slopes. It also comes with an IP54 protection rating, meaning that it is suitable for use in all weather conditions. The product comes with an eye-watering price tag, however, and will set buyers back by £14,520.65. And unlike traditional pooches, it has the limitation of battery life, which is three hours but can quickly be replenished with a replacement power bank.

Elsewhere in the world of robotics, one company has announced plans to ship 100,000 humanoid bots over the next four years. The news comes after Figure AI, who specializes in “giving artificial intelligence a body”, signed a contract with BMW last year – their first commercial customer. The robot dog lasts just three hours before needing to be recharged. They currently have a “fleet” in the works for the brand, performing “end-to-end operations” – and it appears they are focused on expanding further. Founder of Figure AI, Brett Adcock announced they see the potential of shipping 100,000 “humanoid robots” over the next four years. The company has recently signed its second commercial customer, which Adcock doesn’t name but describes as “one of the biggest US companies”. In an update on their work with BMW, Figure AI claims it to be an “autonomous fleet” operating 400% faster and with seven-times higher success rate than before. The company says its mission is to “expand human capabilities through advanced AI”, citing “unprecedented labor shortages” across the US. A video shared on their YouTube channel shows a humanoid making a cup of coffee with a machine, after being vocally given the order by a staff member. In the clip, it says the robot – called ‘Figure 01’ – has “learned to self-correct mistakes”, such as not placing the coffee pod at the right angle.

title: Nvidia AI investment strategy : Inside its top startup bets
content:
Nvidia’s AI investment strategy: Inside its top startup bets

Nvidia, has considerably increased its investments in startups, especially in the AI space. According to PitchBook data, last year alone, the company participated in 49 funding rounds for AI firms, up from 34 in 2023. When comparing the funding by rival tech players, Alphabet leads with 73 deals, followed by Microsoft with 40 deals. However, Nvidia has surpassed both, with 83 deals.

Key investments:

Perplexity:
Nvidia has been a consistent backer of the AI search engine startup since November 2023. In December 2024, Perplexity AI closed a $500 million funding round, tripling its valuation to $9 billion, as per sources. The company is developing a search product to compete with Alphabet Inc.’s Google.

xAI:
Nvidia participated in the $6 billion funding round of Elon Musk’s xAI, in December.

Live Events Wayve:
Nvidia contributed to a $1.05 billion funding round in May 2024 for the UK-based autonomous driving startup.

Scale AI:
In May, Nvidia joined Amazon, Meta and Accel in a $1 billion investment in Scale AI, which provides data-labelling services for AI model training.

Figure AI:
The robotics startup raised $675 million in February from Nvidia, Microsoft and others.

Mistral AI: Nvidia made a second investment in the French large language model developer, contributing to its $640 million Series B at a $6 billion valuation in June.

title: Meta enters humanoid robotics race , eyes AI - powered consumer robots
content: Meta is stepping into humanoid robotics, competing with firms like Nvidia-backed Figure AI and Tesla. Meta Platforms is setting up a new division within its Reality Labs unit to work on AI-powered humanoid robots designed for physical tasks. Meta Chief Technology Officer Andrew Bosworth mentioned that the robotics product group would focus on developing consumer humanoid robots with a goal of maximizing Llama's platform capabilities. The company has appointed Marc Whitten, former CEO of self-driving car company Cruise, as vice president of robotics. Meta also appointed John Koryl as vice president of retail to focus on boosting direct sales of Meta’s Quest mixed reality headsets and AI wearables. The company plans to strengthen its presence in retail by establishing stores like the Meta Lab pop-up store launched in Los Angeles. Meta has been investing in "embodied AI" research to develop AI assistants capable of perceiving, interpreting, and moving through physical environments. The company aims to develop humanoid robot hardware focused on household chores and create AI models, sensors, and software for other robotics companies to use in their products. Notable figures in AI, such as computer scientist Fei-Fei Li, have also entered the space with startups focusing on "spatial intelligence." Tesla CEO Elon Musk has promoted Tesla’s humanoid robot, "Optimus," claiming it can handle various daily tasks. Apptronik recently secured funding to scale up production of humanoid robots designed for warehouse and manufacturing tasks.

title: OpenAI might enter the humanoid robot : Here all we know - Technology News
content: OpenAI, the artificial intelligence (AI) company, is planning to enter the humanoid robot sector in 2024. The company had previously shut down its robot division in 2021 but is now looking to make a fresh start. OpenAI is also collaborating with TSMC and Broadcom to develop its first in-house chip to support its AI systems. Additionally, the company has been investing in robotic startups such as Physical Intelligence, Figure AI, and 1X Technologies, which are working on building humanoid robots and developing artificial general intelligence (AGI). OpenAI is also planning to develop a reasoning model and an AI agent to automate software engineering and analysis tasks. Other players in the humanoid robot space include Tesla Bot and Atlas by Boston Dynamics.

title: Apptronik raises $350 million to scale production of humanoid robots
content:
Apptronik raises $350 million to scale production of humanoid robots
Apptronik said on Thursday it has raised $350 million in a funding round led by B Capital and Capital Factory, with participation from Alphabet's Google, to scale production of AI-powered humanoid robots. The Austin, Texas-based company is developing Apollo, a human-like or humanoid robot whose tasks will include working in warehouses and manufacturing plants by moving packages and other supply chain-oriented tasks. Apptronik joins the ranks of rivals like Tesla and Nvidia-backed Figure AI in the race to develop human-like robots as advancements in artificial intelligence lead to significant breakthroughs in robotics and automation. In October last year, Tesla CEO Elon Musk said that "a lot of progress" has been made with its humanoid robot "Optimus" that could perform many daily tasks. CEO and co-founder of Apptronik, Jeff Cardenas, mentioned in an interview with Reuters that 2025 is expected to see a lot of activity for robotics. The company plans to expand the capabilities of Apollo to other industries including elder care and healthcare, and has partnerships with Google DeepMind robotics team, as well as commercial agreements with Mercedes-Benz and GXO Logistics for its humanoid robots.

title: Humanoid robots : From science fiction to economic reality
content:
Humanoid robots: From science fiction to economic reality
January 09, 2025 at 10:33 am EST
By The editorial team

Humanoid robots, long confined to science fiction stories, are now at the heart of a technological revolution thanks to advances in artificial intelligence (AI). These machines, capable of learning and adapting, promise to transform various industrial and societal sectors. This article explores the evolution of these automata, recent innovations, challenges and prospects for investors.

Generative artificial intelligence has made a quantum leap in the field of robotics. Robots can now learn by imitating, much as we do. Imagine a robot that watches a video of someone folding laundry and can then do the same thing, even if the conditions change a little.

Last summer, Tesla boss Elon Musk announced that their Optimus humanoid robot could be on the market by the end of 2025. He even thinks it could boost Tesla's value to $25,000 billion.

The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) has launched a study group to examine the world of humanoid robots and establish standards that companies could follow. The group is open to academics, government agencies and industry players alike.

Boston Dynamics presented the new version of its Atlas humanoid robot in April 2024. This model is fully electric, more powerful and more agile than its predecessor.

Agility Robotics has collaborated with Manhattan Associates to integrate bipedal humanoid robots into warehouses.

Figure.ai, a manufacturer of humanoid robots, joined forces with OpenAI in March 2024 to integrate OpenAI's AI into its robots.

Beijing has decided to go all out on robotics with a $1.4 billion fund launched in August 2023. The idea is to boost technological innovation, advance commercial projects and support mergers and acquisitions in the sector.

But Canada is not to be outdone. At the end of 2022, the government invested $30 million in Sanctuary Cognitive Systems, a Vancouver-based company that manufactures versatile humanoid robots. Sanctuary Cognitive Systems has teamed up with Magna International to improve humanoid robots for automotive manufacturing. The partnership aims to make these robots more affordable and scalable, using Magna's engineering and manufacturing expertise.

On the military front, the use of ground combat robots capable of firing is no longer a science-fiction concept, but a reality in contemporary conflicts. Currently, during the war in Ukraine, alongside FPV aerial drones and naval drones, Ukrainian forces are deploying small wheeled robots equipped with machine guns against Russian troops. The Russians, meanwhile, have pioneered this field by deploying heavy Uran-9 robots in Syria, with apparently mixed results. The major military powers have all developed drones or machines which, although far removed from humanoids, incorporate automation and are capable of replacing certain human functions in high-risk missions.

In short, robotics is making great strides, and artificial intelligence is playing a key role in this revolution. Investments are pouring in, collaborations are multiplying, and innovations never cease to surprise.

Challenges and growth prospects
The market for humanoid robots is booming. In 2023, it was already worth $2.43 billion, and could reach $66 billion by 2032, with annual growth of 45.5%, according to Forbes.

title: Figure AI details plan to improve humanoid robot safety in the workplace
content:
Figure AI details plan to improve humanoid robot safety in the workplace

Safety is often overlooked in the rush to bring humanoid robots to the workplace. As high-profile corporations ranging from retailers like Amazon to carmakers such as Mercedes and BMW have announced humanoid pilots for factories and warehouses, conversations around worker safety are regularly buried beneath industry hype.

One Bay Area robotics firm, Figure AI, is hoping to correct that shortfall. They announced the building of a Center for the Advancement of Humanoid Safety, an in-house division wholly focused on the topic. Rob Gruendel, the former Amazon Robotics safety engineer heading up the project, revealed the plans via a LinkedIn post.

Earlier factory and warehouse systems addressed the safety problem by caging in big, heavy robots. Subsequent solutions have turned to technology, including advanced computer vision, software developed by Veo Robotics, and a safety vest designed by Amazon to help keep robots from crashing into people.

Figure AI is homing in on the gap in safety standards for humanoid robots. They have finalized a formal plan with an OSHA recognized independent testing laboratory to certify their robot's battery, functional safety control system, and electrical system to industrial standards.

The creation of the Center for the Advancement of Humanoid Safety is an important step in addressing safety concerns related to humanoid robots working alongside humans in factories and warehouses. The firm plans to publish quarterly updates offering more transparency around the safety testing procedures and fixes for potential hazards.

Humanoid safety standards are set to become increasingly essential as more firms push to bring these robots into the home. The industry is preparing for the next big leap of bringing robots into domestic settings, and ensuring safety standards are in place is crucial for this transition.

title: Meta plans investments into AI - driven humanoid robots , memo shows
content: Meta Platforms is establishing a new division within its Reality Labs unit to develop AI-powered humanoid robots that can assist with physical tasks, according to an internal company memo viewed by Reuters on Friday. Facebook parent Meta is entering the competitive field of humanoid robotics, joining rivals such as Nvidia-backed Figure AI and Tesla, as the emergence of advanced AI models drives innovation in robotics and automation. In the memo, Meta Chief Technology Officer Andrew Bosworth said the robotics product group would focus on research and development involving "consumer humanoid robots with a goal of maximizing Llama's platform capabilities." Llama is the name of Meta's main series of AI foundation models, which power a growing suite of generative AI products on the company's social media platforms. "We believe expanding our portfolio to invest in this field will only accrue value to Meta AI and our mixed and augmented reality programs," Bosworth wrote. The group will be led by Marc Whitten, the former CEO of self-driving car company Cruise, whom Meta has hired as vice president of robotics, Bosworth said in the memo. The news was first reported by Bloomberg News. Bosworth said the company also hired John Koryl as vice president of retail. Koryl, who was formerly CEO of second-hand e-commerce company The RealReal, was hired to expand efforts to sell directly to consumers Meta's Quest mixed reality headsets and AI wearables such as Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses, which Meta makes with eyewear maker EssilorLuxottica. Meta aims to build "more direct expertise in the space" by developing retail locations like the Meta Lab temporary store it opened in Los Angeles in November, although retail partners will continue to drive the bulk of hardware sales volume, Bosworth said. Meta did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment. The announcement represents a major bet on Meta's Reality Labs unit, which is aimed at developing technologies to drive future growth but has hemorrhaged money since its establishment. The unit lost about $5 billion in the fourth quarter of last year. Major tech companies and startups are pouring billions into developing AI-powered devices for manufacturing, logistics and household tasks. Progress on robots has been slow, however, as researchers have found that the language-related AI breakthroughs driving chatbot development have not necessarily helped with understanding of the physical world. Meta for years has been funding research into "embodied AI," hoping to develop AI assistants that can look at, listen to and navigate the 3D physical world around them. The company's top AI scientist, Yann LeCun, also has been vocal about highlighting the limitations of language models and trying to develop new types of models that can better understand physical space. Prominent computer scientist Fei-Fei Li jumped into the race last year with the launch of her "spatial intelligence" startup World Labs, while Tesla CEO Elon Musk has said that his company's humanoid robot "Optimus" can perform many daily tasks and will eventually be sold to customers. On Thursday, Apptronik secured $350 million in funding backed by investors including Alphabet's Google to scale the production of its AI-powered humanoid robots designed for tasks in warehouses and manufacturing plants. Meta plans to develop its own humanoid robot hardware, initially targeting household chores, while aiming to create AI, sensors and software that can power robots manufactured and sold by various companies, according to the Bloomberg report. Meta has started discussing its plan with robotics companies, including Unitree Robotics and Figure AI, and does not immediately plan to launch its own branded robot, the report said. (Reporting by Katie Paul in New York and Harshita Mary Varghese in Bengaluru; additional reporting by Jaspreet Singh in Bengaluru; Editing by Alan Barona and Leslie Adler)

title: Nvidia believes the robotics market is about to explode , just like ChatGPT
content: Nvidia believes the robotics market is about to explode, just like ChatGPT. The company is pivoting to powering humanoid robotics as AI chips experience stiffening competition. A report by The Financial Times highlights how Deepu Talla, Nvidia's VP of robotics, believes the robotics market has reached an inflection point where physical AI and robotics are about to take off in a big way. Nvidia wants to position itself as the go-to platform for robotics and is planning to launch its latest robot brain called Jetson Thor next year. The robotics market is projected to soar from $78 billion currently to $165 billion by the end of 2029, per BCC Research.

title: OpenAI eyes consumer hardware market with potential AI - powered devices , humanoid robots
content: OpenAI may be preparing to expand beyond software and step into the consumer hardware space, including AI-powered smart devices and humanoid robots. A new trademark application filed with the US Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) on January 31 lists a variety of potential products, from wearable tech and AR/VR headsets to AI chipsets and programmable robots. The mention of quantum-powered AI chipsets is particularly significant, as OpenAI has previously focused on optimizing large language models like ChatGPT. This suggests a possible shift toward developing AI-specific hardware to reduce reliance on existing chipmakers like Nvidia and AMD. The mention of humanoid robots aligns with OpenAI's growing investment in robotics. The company is a backer of Figure AI, 1X Technologies, and Physical Intelligence, all of which are developing next-generation robotic systems. Additionally, OpenAI has previously listed job openings for research engineers in robotics, fueling speculation that it could be working on human-like AI-driven robots. CEO Sam Altman recently spoke about the company's interest in AI-powered devices, suggesting that OpenAI is exploring partnerships to develop generative AI-powered consumer products. Despite the ambitious trademark filing, OpenAI has not yet confirmed any hardware development plans.

title: Meta is also interested in making humanoid robots
content: Meta is also interested in making humanoid robots. According to industry analyst Mark Gurman’s report for Bloomberg, Meta is investing heavily in AI-powered humanoid robots. The company's goal is to create robots that can help with household chores and act like humans. Meta's new robotics division will be led by Marc Whitten, who will hire 100 engineers this year for the development team. Apple and OpenAI are also reportedly working on humanoid robots, with Apple exploring both humanoid and non-humanoid robots for its smart home ecosystem. OpenAI has filed a trademark application for humanoid robots. It is unclear when these companies will launch their robots.

title: Elon Musk : More money for training humanoid robot Tesla Optimus Bot
content: Elon Musk intends to invest more money in the training infrastructure for the humanoid robot Optimus Bot. Musk made this statement to investors on Wednesday. Training a robot with artificial intelligence (AI) is significantly more complex than that of a Tesla electric vehicle. The training requirements are around 10 times higher than for a car. Musk believes that the Optimus Bot has the potential to generate sales of 10 billion dollars. The robot is expected to be delivered to the first customers in 2026.

title: Jensen Huang Nvidia  Printing Money Like Apple  In Early iPhone Days , Says Tesla Bull Ross Gerber - NVIDIA ( NASDAQ : NVDA )
content:
Jensen Huang's Nvidia 'Printing Money Like Apple' In Early iPhone Days, Says Tesla Bull Ross Gerber
Nvidia Corp. is on the cusp of a significant growth phase, fueled by its leadership in AI infrastructure. Investor Ross Gerber compared Jensen Huang's chip giant current financial trajectory to Apple Inc. during the early iPhone years, highlighting the immense potential in AI. Gerber sees Nvidia's growth driven by the global development of AI infrastructure, largely supported by Nvidia's cutting-edge chips. Nvidia has drawn $30 billion in retail investor inflows this year, making it the most favored stock among retail investors in 2024. Despite some traders offloading shares, Nvidia's stock has surged 181% year to date. Nvidia's founder and CEO, Jensen Huang, is set to speak at CES 2025, potentially further boosting the stock. Nvidia's strategic focus on robotics as a new growth driver comes amid fierce competition in the AI chipmaking sector. Nvidia's valuation has surpassed $3 trillion, rivaling Apple Inc., fueled by the AI boom. The company has also invested in humanoid robotics firms like Figure AI, marking its entry into 'physical AI.' Ibiden Co., a key supplier for Nvidia, is considering expanding its production capacity to meet the surging demand for AI chip package substrates. Ibiden's new substrate factory in Gifu, Japan, is expected to begin operations at 25% capacity by late 2025, eventually reaching 50% by March 2026. Price Action: Nvidia was trading slightly lower at $137.24 in overnight trading hours on Robinhood at 2:19 am ET.

title: Softest Humanoid Bot ? 1X NEO Gamma Debuts New Home Helper Clothed in 3D - Printed Nylon Fabric
content:
1X Technologies has debuted a humanoid robot called NEO Gamma. This humanoid robot can do everything at home, and it acts like a nanny that can attend to various needs of the household like cleaning, picking up laundry, and bringing items from one place to another. The robot features a 3D-printed nylon fabric skin-like finish that makes it stand out from other humanoid bots in the market.

1X Technologies has been sharing new videos about its latest robotic development, the NEO Gamma, which features a soft "skin" that covers its exterior. The company explained that it was made from 3D-printed nylon fabric that covers its body, giving it less of a machine-like appearance that is more suited for the home. The design focuses on a minimalistic approach to its aesthetic that fits the home, and apart from its 3D-printed nylon fabric, it also features Emotive Ear Rings for improved communication.

In its demo video, NEO Gamma can help in vacuuming, watering the plants, carrying laundry, delivering items humans ask for, cleaning up at home, and a whole lot more. Robotics have evolved over the past years, and they are no longer the clunky, metal machines that were once the standard as they are now taking the likeness and capabilities of humans. Tesla's Optimus and Figure AI Inc.'s Figure 02 are examples of humanoid bots being developed to help people in various tasks and needs.

title: The Prompt : Meta Faces Backlash Over AI Profiles
content: Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg said the move will allow the company to simplify its policies and restore "free expression on our platforms.” Earlier today, Meta announced that it plans to “restore free speech” on its platforms by gutting independent fact checkers, who have been responsible for moderating content and reviewing misinformation, and replacing them with an X-style community notes model, where users provide additional context on misleading posts. The social media giant is also leaning on AI to provide a “second opinion” on its decisions regarding removing and restoring content. This comes just days after Meta faced backlash for AI-generated accounts on Instagram and Facebook that were sloppy and lied to human users (It quickly took down the AI profiles). The company has also started showing users AI-generated versions of themselves in different scenarios, 404 Media reported.

title: Inside Jeff Bezo Personal Investments
content:
Here Are The Startups Jeff Bezos Invested In Last Year

Jeff Bezos has been busy since stepping down from his CEO post at Amazon in 2021: investing in startups and real estate, continuing to spend time at Amazon and Blue Origin, and cozying up to president-elect Trump. "I've actually never worked harder," he told the New York Times in December.

The billionaire Amazon founder put early money into Airbnb and Uber. Now he’s placing bets on these AI robotics companies.

Before Marko Bjelonic, co-founder and CEO of AI robotics company Swiss-Mile, met with billionaire Jeff Bezos last April, he sent Bezos his version of an Amazon 6-Pager to pitch his company, hoping it would improve his odds in a video call he expected to feel rushed—but wasn’t. The call led Bezos to co-lead a $22 million funding round in Zurich-based Swiss-Mile in August. Swiss-Mile is developing AI-powered robots that can deliver items from point to point.

Swiss-Mile is one of at least nine companies that got investments from Bezos in 2024; seven of them are artificial intelligence startups, according to media reports, PitchBook and Preqin data and Forbes research. Bezos made investments in companies like Figure AI, Swiss-Mile, and Skild AI, focusing on AI-powered robotics, a vertical he had not publicly focused on as a venture investor before last year.

Bezos has personally invested in at least 108 startups across all industries since he first put $250,000 into Google in 1998. He has placed early bets on companies like Twitter, Airbnb, Uber, and Nextdoor, and continues to be actively involved in his venture portfolio.

In addition to robotics startups, Bezos also backed companies like controversial AI-powered search engine Perplexity AI, chip designer Tenstorrent, fintech firm Outgo, and caregiver support firm Magnolia. Bezos' investments in these companies reflect his interest in cutting-edge technologies and industries.

Overall, Bezos' investments in startups show his continued interest in innovation and emerging technologies, as well as his strategic approach to diversifying his investment portfolio beyond Amazon.

title: Meta Is Looking to Get Into the AI Humanoid Robot Business
content:
Meta Is Looking to Get Into the AI Humanoid Robot Business
Meta Platforms has moved beyond trying to connect humans and is ready to focus on building robotic ones. According to a report from Bloomberg, Meta is planning to pour money into a new project to build AI-powered humanoid robots. Meta reportedly plans to start the project by building a robot capable of completing household chores. The effort will be headed up by Marc Whitten, who was serving as CEO of self-driving car company Cruise before resigning earlier this month. Whitten’s team will fall under Meta’s Reality Labs division, which is coming off a modest success with its Meta Ray-Ban smart glasses. Meta reportedly believes these bots are still several years away from being available, and that it’s even farther out from being able to serve as the underpinning AI that will be used by robotics companies for their machines.

title: Report : Meta Betting on AI - Powered Humanoid Robots
content:
Meta is betting big on humanoid AI-powered robots, as reported by Bloomberg. The company has formed a new division within its Reality Labs unit to focus on developing hardware for robots that can assist with physical tasks like household chores. Led by Marc Whitten, the division plans to hire 100 engineers in 2025 and has already begun talks with robotics companies like Unitree Robotics and Figure AI.

Rather than launching a branded robot like Tesla's Optimus, Meta plans to develop AI systems, sensors, and software for robots that will be manufactured and sold by other companies. The company aims for its upcoming LLaMA language model to become a foundation for robotics researchers worldwide.

While Meta will build prototypes for testing purposes, it may not launch a consumer-facing robot in the near future. The division is expected to leverage data collected from Meta's AR and VR devices to advance robotics. Apple is also exploring humanoid and non-humanoid robots for its smart home ecosystem, while Nvidia predicts a $38 billion market for humanoid robotics in the coming years.

title: Nvidia  Cosmo AI Helps Humanoid Robots Navigate the World
content:
Nvidia’s ‘Cosmos’ AI Helps Humanoid Robots Navigate the World
Nvidia announced today it’s releasing a family of foundational AI models called Cosmos that can be used to train humanoids, industrial robots, and self-driving cars. While language models learn how to generate text by training on copious amounts of books, articles, and social media posts, Cosmos is designed to generate images and 3D models of the physical world. During a keynote presentation at the annual CES conference in Las Vegas, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang showed examples of Cosmos being used to simulate activities inside of warehouses. Cosmos was trained on 20 million hours of real footage of “humans walking, hands moving, manipulating things,” Jensen said. “It’s not about generating creative content, but teaching the AI to understand the physical world." Researchers and startups hope that these kinds of foundational models could give robots used in factories and homes more sophisticated capabilities. Cosmos can, for example, generate realistic video footage of boxes falling from shelves inside a warehouse, which can be used to train a robot to recognize accidents. Users can also fine-tune the models using their own data. A number of companies are already using Cosmos, Nvidia says, including humanoid robot startups Agility and Figure AI as well as self-driving car companies like Uber, Waabi, and Wayve. Nvidia also announced software designed to help different kinds of robots learn to perform new tasks more efficiently. The new feature is part of Nvidia’s existing Isaac robot simulation platform that will allow robot builders to take a small number of examples of a desired task, like grasping a particular object, and generate large amounts of synthetic training data. Nvidia hopes that Cosmos and Isaac will appeal to companies looking to build and use humanoid robots. Jensen was joined on stage at CES by life-sized images of 14 different humanoid robots developed by companies including Tesla, Boston Dynamics, Agility, and Figure. Along with Cosmos, Nvidia also announced Project Digits, a $3,000 “personal AI supercomputer” that can run a large language model of up to 200 billion parameters without the need of cloud services from the likes of AWS or Microsoft. It also announced its highly anticipated next-generation RTX Blackwell GPUs and incoming software tools to help build AI agents.

title: Meta is reportedly working on humanoid robots that help with chores
content: Meta is reportedly working on humanoid robots that help with chores. Bloomberg reported on Friday that Meta plans to leverage its advances in AI and augmented reality to build a platform for futuristic humanoid robots that can help with household chores like folding laundry. Meta is reportedly creating a new team within its Reality Labs hardware division, which handles Quest VR headsets and the long-term Orion AR glasses project. Although it will build robot hardware during development, Meta’s long-term goal is more like Android, where Google makes the software platform that almost all of the industry (outside of Apple) uses. Meta would make the underlying sensors, AI and software for other companies to put inside their hardware. In other words, it wants to be the Android of androids. At least initially, Meta plans to make household chores the project’s central focus. Folding laundry, carrying glasses of water, putting dinnerware in the dishwasher, and other home chores are examples mentioned. Meta has reportedly held early discussions with the Chinese robotics company Unitree and California-based humanoid robot maker Figure AI. Meta Chief Technology Officer Andrew Bosworth reportedly views the company’s progress in hand tracking, low-bandwidth computing, and always-on sensors as advantages for developing humanoid robots. Last year, news broke that Apple and Google were also working on robotics. Flying cars may have to wait, but the idea of household robots like Rosey from The Jetsons is becoming more of a reality.

title: Report : Meta is planning a  major investment  into humanoid robotics
content:
Report: Meta is planning a "major investment" into humanoid robotics
Bloomberg has reported that Meta is betting on humanoid robots as it plans a "major investment" into the field. The company is reportedly forming a new team within its Reality Labs division that will work on the futuristic robots.
Meta employees have already been informed of this new team, and it will be led by former Cruise CEO Marc Whitten, who has held significant positions at Amazon, Sonos, and Microsoft, where he was a founding engineer on the Xbox team.
Humanoid robots are notoriously difficult to get right. The human anatomy is very complex, and replicating such movement of the human body requires sophisticated hardware and design.
There is also the fact that humanoid robots that display human-like emotions and behaviors can lead to something called "Cognitive Anthropomorphism", which is when people attribute mental states to them that they do not possess. This could raise ethical dilemmas and unrealistic expectations. These are some of the challenges Meta will face in its work on humanoid robots.
Two companies are already in talks with Meta: Unitree Robotics and Figure AI Inc. The latter raised $500 million in funding from Microsoft and OpenAI last year. The field of humanoid robotics is already crowded with competitors like Tesla and its Optimus robot, Boston Dynamics and its Atlas robot, Samsung, and even Apple.
Meta is not really known for its hardware expertise. Apart from its lineup of smart glasses and VR headsets, it does not seem to have much experience, especially given the existing competitors.
However, Meta execs are optimistic about the company's chances, citing an advantage they believe Meta has over others, which is data and its vast experience with AI. Meta's CTO, Andrew Bosworth, said the following in a memo:
The core technologies we’ve already invested in and built across Reality Labs and AI are complementary to developing the advancements needed for robotics.
While Meta plans to build some of the hardware for its humanoid robots, it ultimately aims to be the Google of the robotics industry, offering the platform, software, sensors, and AI for other manufacturers to build their robots.

title: Apple humanoid robot could have one huge advantage as Meta announces its project
content:
Apple humanoid robot could have one huge advantage as Meta announces its project

A new report suggests that Apple and Meta could end up competing in the humanoid robots field. The social media company is said to be making “significant investment” in this product category, with a focus on household chores. But if Apple does proceed with its own reported domestic robot plans, the Cupertino company could have a huge advantage.

Apple is already rumored to be working on a sci-fi humanoid robot capable of performing domestic chores. Bloomberg described this as a “skunk-works project,” indicating a small team working on it independently from the main product development roadmap.

Meta, on the other hand, has developed a strong interest in AI-powered humanoid robots, focusing on household chores. The company plans to work on its own humanoid robot hardware and has started discussing its plan with robotics companies.

The competition between Apple and Meta in the humanoid robot field could accelerate the timeline for the development of truly capable domestic robots. While autonomous robots have been primarily used for commercial purposes, the transition to domestic work may take longer due to different price points consumer robots have to hit.

Having a humanoid robot in the home could raise privacy concerns, but Apple's focus on privacy and reputation could give it a significant advantage in this area. This advantage could play a crucial role in the adoption of humanoid robots in households.

Overall, the competition between Apple and Meta in the humanoid robot market could lead to advancements in the field and potentially bring these robots into mainstream use sooner than expected.

title: Mass roll - out of AI - powered humanoid worker robots coming in the next few years
content:
Mass roll-out of AI-powered humanoid worker robots coming in the next few years

Robots in the workplace has long been the realm of science fiction - but now it's a reality. A fleet of 100,000 humanoid robots is set to shipped out over the next four years by a boundary-breaking artificial intelligence company - meaning your next co-worker just might be made of metal.

A year ago, Figure AI signed with car manufacturer BMW and now has a “fleet of robots performing end-to-end operations”. Figure's CEO Brett Adcock announced on LinkedIn last month that the company had now signed another client, which was "one of the biggest US companies" and would give Figure the potential to ship the humanoids at high volumes.

Adcock said that between BMW and Figure's new signing, he believes there is a path to “100,000 robots over the next four years”. He explained Figure is currently working on training the robots on carrying out work at high speeds and high performance.

Figure, founded by Adcock in 2022, aims to deploy autonomous humanoid workers to support humans on a global scale. Its humanoid robot, called Figure 02, is AI-powered and self-reliant, and is described as being “ready to produce an abundance of affordable, more widely available goods and services to a degree which humanity has never seen”.

Figure 02 is 5ft 6ins, can run for five hours on a charge, and move at 1.2 metres per second. The machine combines the "dexterity of the human form" with "cutting edge AI" to be able to lend support across manufacturing, logistics, warehousing, and retail.

The robots are meant to eliminate the need for unsafe and undesirable jobs, Adcock explains, which he says will allow future generations to “live happier, more purposeful lives”. He writes on Figure’s website that the company envisions a future where “humanoid robots are the universal interface in the physical world”.

While the robots will perform corporate tasks in areas with “significant” labour shortages and jobs that are unsafe or undesirable in the early days, in the long term, these humanoids could assist people at home, care for the elderly, or build new worlds on other planets, Figure says. Adcock was named on Time Magazine’s list of 100 Most Influential People in AI in 2024 and told the outlet that the robot could perform 80 to 90 per cent of manual human tasks.

“Eventually, physical labour will be optional,” he said. “You’ll choose to do it, or you’ll ask your Figure robot to do it”.

title: Thursday March 13th - Open Thread - The Last Refuge
content:
Thursday March 13th – Open Thread

Our Father, who art in heaven, hallowed be thy Name. Thy kingdom come. THY WILL BE DONE, on earth as it is in heaven. Give us this day our daily bread. And forgive us our trespasses, as we forgive those who trespass against us. And lead us not into temptation, but DELIVER US FROM EVIL.
For Thine is the kingdom and the power and the glory, forever and ever. Amen †

We humbly ask that You please comfort those who are grieving and in pain.
And prayers up for all political prisoners. Prayers up for Julian Assange and for all the protesters of January 6 who were or are entrapped in DC.
